@neil_ferguson @niaid @cepi If nCoV spreads widely in the world, it will be in strong interest of all countries, to keep trade going despite the pandemic– global economy is highly interdependent.  Govs would need to work w/ orgs like WTO and travel industry orgs like IATA to keep goods, people moving.(22/x)

@neil_ferguson The work to prepare for the possibility of failed containment could be called something like:  Plan for Global Mobilization to Respond to a nCoV Pandemic.  There are a series of highest priorities that should be at the top of that Plan, including:  (9/x)

@UNMC_DrKhan Thanks for flagging @UNMC_DrKhan. @JHSPH_CHS put this exercise on w @wef & @gatesfoundation.  Used fictional coronavirus w/ different characteristics as current nCoV in China.  Purpose was to highlight global vulnerabilities to pandemics. We made no predictions about future (1/X)

@ldpsci @mlipsitch Our commentary agues that research that makes highly virulent viruses more transmissible should have more oversight and transparency.  we describe specifically what we mean by that.  We have argued for more R&D for coronavirus vaccines and diagnostics for years (2/x)

@ldpsci @mlipsitch on the contrary, the commentary argues that we should not be doing research that transforms coronaviruses that can't effectively spread in humans, into coronaviruses that can.  @mlipsitch and I are both strongly pro-scientific research on coronaviruses (1/x)
